description:
This article backs up our recommendation to NOT offer a reward online for your missing pet.  In addition, we want to remind you that you do not need to pay any website or service to list your missing pet.  There are many, many FREE services like HelpingLostPets.com that will list your pet for FREE. And we are also partnered with many amazing volunteer groups across the country.

https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2017-10-16-beware-social-media-scammers-when-posting-a-reward-for-lost-pets/

We meet people every day that would climb a mountain to find their missing pet. This is why we are so driven to get EVERY LOST AND FOUND PET LISTED ON ONE Database.

We have partnered with so many amazing volunteer groups that are helping across the country. In addition, our Matchmakers group is growing. 

If you have a missing pet and you have not listed with us, you can list for free, The next Match made might be for your pet. Please use this link to list: http://www.HelpinglostPets.com/PET

Are you someone that likes to match lost and found pets? Join our Matchmakers group and we will teach you how to use HelpingLostPets.com. Just email us at info@helpinglostpets.com

A special 2-part #FiveSibes #TheSibeVibe #LostDog series on @DogWorksRadio:  "Help me! I'm Lost! - What To Do If You've Lost or Found a Dog" hosted by Hudson Valley's award-winning author DOROTHY WILLS-RAFTERY featuring guests KATHY POBLOSKIE, director and co-founder of Lost Dogs of Wisconsin (LDoW) & co-founder of Lost Dogs of America and BARB MCDONALD, volunteer at LDoW and admin of Lost/found Husky Dogs. 

To listen to PART 1, visit: http://dogworksradio.com/the-sibe-vibe-what-if-you-have-lost-or-found-a-dog/

To listen to PART 2, visit:  http://dogworksradio.com/what-if-you-have-lost-or-found-a-dog-part-2/  

Please subscribe to Dog Works Radio on iTunes to hear all the shows, including "The Sibe Vibe!"

It was a match!!!

A dog picked up from Walton County Animal Control and her listing uploaded to helpinglostpets.com and shared to the public. An owner filing a lost report with the shelter via the helpinglostpets.com system and the same alert going out to the public. This is what a match looks like with helpinglostpets.com and this system helped Hartley get home today!

Thank you to everyone who shared and to Walton County Animal Control for their continued use of the program! ONE central database for lost and found pets does get more pets home!

To learn more about helpinglostpets.com and to see how it can help your shelter, please watch this video from Walton County Animal Control on all the benefits of HeLP.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/BHNO0OO3OVE

To add your shelter today, go to: www.HelpingLostPets.com/ORG
Pete Mayher lost his yellow labrador, Wizzer, five years ago on Fort Myers Beach. Over the years, hope for finding him waned, until three weeks ago, when Hurricane Irma ripped through Florida.

Home at last after 5 years missing! This Chihuahua from #Chicago #IL is home safe & sound. Message: "He was taken to the vet who found a chip in him. His family was contacted and they are very happy to have him back! Apparently they have been looking for him for the last five years!!" Missing 09/25/2012. Reunited 09/27/2017. Chips really work! Welcome home Mohave!
Grand Junction - With the deluge of recent natural disasters happening around the world, I am thankful to live in this beautiful area that is typically

Coming Home - Using Helping Lost Pets (HeLP)

I first learned about Helping Lost Pets late last year. It is a free, map-based website used to help pets get back home after they have gone missing or are stolen. I promote this website because it interacts with other sites, offers free posters for individual people to use and is easy for animal control agencies to use. Within a few days of beginning to use HeLP for my animal control officer, we were able to get a dog back home who had been missing for more than 3 months. She was found hundreds of miles from her home after having been stolen by some contractors.

I have blogged about HeLP a couple of times.

http://www.paws4change.com/blog/a-little-help-from-your-friends-getting-lost-pets-home

http://www.paws4change.com/blog/your-pet-is-lost-or-has-been-stolen-now-what

Please take a little time to learn about this wonderful resource. We have a lot of lost and found pages on social media all operating independently of each other. While the work of these pages is great, some are closed groups and in the end, animals don't know geographic boundaries and can end up many miles from the location we expect them to be. By using HeLP as the primary platform, we really can harness the power of the Internet to get lost pets back home.

Pet Looting

Here's the scenario. You're at your house near Houston. It is not yet flooded.  You think you're going to be safe.  The Army Corps of Engineers opens a dam and with very little warning your house begins filling up with water. You frantically start grabbing things to load up in a vehicle in hopes that you can get out in time. In the process of loading things into a vehicle your dog gets out. You had him leashed and with you all the time, but he's  scared and feeding off of your fear so he pulls away from you. You call for him. You search high and low, but you have to go. Authorities come along, telling you to get in a rescue vehicle right now. You say, "but I don't know where my dog is," and they say, "don't worry. Someone will find your dog and take care of him." You panic and you leave as you call out for your dog.

I think it is easy for people to find fault with those who did not leave the Houston area with their pets. I get that. But it's not always the result of irresponsibility.

I fully support rescue groups that have gone into the affected areas of Texas and who have pulled animals from shelters in order to free up space for local pets to be housed temporarily. I do not support rescue groups who have gone into an affected areas and picked up pets to take them away to points unknown. How in the world are people supposed to find their pets if they've been taken away to another state? For me this is nothing short of pet looting. I know that most people mean well, but they should be pulling unowned animals and leaving the potentially owned animals in the immediate area.

If you have never lived through a natural disaster you have no idea how you will behave during times of extreme stress. Let's give everyone the benefit of the doubt before we judge them for the animals who are now displaced from home.

We have partnered with so many amazing volunteer groups that are helping across the country. In addition, our Matchmakers group is growing.

August 15th is a Great Day to Check the Chip!

This is a GOOD NEWS story, so of course it is less likely to be SHAREd and LIKEed.  Sorry no grusome photos of animals abused or animal abusers needing to be identified.

There are many shelters that do a great job of trying to find pet owners and when volunteer groups like Lost Dogs of Wisconsin (LDWI) and Lost Cats of Wisconsin (LCWI) help, the number of pet reunions goes way UP!!  We are proud to partner with LCWI and LDWI and many other volunteer groups across the country.  We also partner with shelters too.

Please let your shelter know about HelpingLostPets.com. It's FREE, it's INTERNATIONAL and the volunteer groups we partner with make us the #1 Lost Pet Website in the WORLD!!
